text: mary-elizabeth arwen high school in
downtown Manhattan offers a snapshot of
how the country's financial crisis is
trickling down to nearly everyone
although they don't work on Wall Street
and may not own stocks the students here
say they are feeling the pinch of a
slumping economy definitely today I was
really nervous you know just I always
get coffee in the morning and I was sort
of like oh no should I not do this we're
not very good cooks in my house so we
normally we don't go out but we'll order
like pizza or Chinese food or Mexican
food but now we're kind of saving our
money and buying I guess in bulk
Elizabeth arwen is a private school
tuition is thirty one thousand dollars
and thirty six percent of the students
receive financial aid check out your
knees
thomas murphy teaches a class for 11th
and 12th graders called economics and
society the financial crisis is bringing
his curriculum home in a new way I've
watched it involved over the last couple
of weeks I think that initially it was
seen as something that was distant and
didn't really pertain to most of them
and just in the last two weeks you're
starting to get a sense that parents are
beginning to talk about diminished
expectations but I don't know if that's
actually translated into wait you can't
buy that for many of the kids they
couldn't buy it to begin with but for
the others I think the reassessment is
just happening the assumption is that
housing prices were always going to go
on but what happens if the housing
prices dropped exactly you'll stop you
can't get out from underneath your
mortgage you can sell the house last and
say you know I took out a mortgage
14,000 I sold the house for 250,000 you
gotta eat 50,000 bank know the bank's
like you owe me fifty thousand on top of
this now you're homeless Joe and your
$50,000 further in the hole taking out a
mortgage that's such an old thing to do
I mean I was always taught that was such
a safe investment and that was what you
did and that was
it's not a part of becoming a grown-up
was eventually I'd get my mortgage and
one so I don't think that was a matter
for my response life yeah five cards are
a little different but my question is
what next and what does it mean for you
in a concrete way many of our kids don't
have 100 150 180 thousand dollars just
sitting in the bank waiting for them for
college and they're worried about can I
get a loan for financial aid typically
in down economies when jobs are scarce
more people go to college but with the
credit crisis many banks have stopped
offering private student loans it is too
soon to know the impact on scholarships
but students are already nervous I feel
like I'm working so hard in school to be
like you know I'm first generation will
go to college and really be try to be
successful in life and now I'm afraid
all my hard work in the end won't be
enough to make it
